text: Not sure if any of you guys read Matt Levine, but he mentioned this article and it seems pretty funny/applicable to your models

text: :smile:
<https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2214804321000641>

attachments.title: Sonic Thunder vs. Brian the Snail: Are people affected by uninformative racehorse names?
attachments.text: This paper examines whether individuals’ decision making is affected by fast-sounding horse names in a betting exchange market environment. In horse r…
attachments.fallback: Sonic Thunder vs. Brian the Snail: Are people affected by uninformative racehorse names?

text: "d lower returns due to the increased demand for these bets. Using over 3 million horse bets, we find evidence that the winning probabilities of bets on horses with fast-sounding names are overstated, which impairs the prediction accuracy of such bets. This finding implies that prices in betting exchange markets are distorted by incorporating affective, misleading information from a horse's fast-sounding name. Consequently, this bias translates into significantly lower betting returns for horses with names classified as fast-sounding compared to the returns for all other horses."

elements.text: "d lower returns due to the increased demand for these bets. Using over 3 million horse bets, we find evidence that the winning probabilities of bets on horses with fast-sounding names are overstated, which impairs the prediction accuracy of such bets. This finding implies that prices in betting exchange markets are distorted by incorporating affective, misleading information from a horse's fast-sounding name. Consequently, this bias translates into significantly lower betting returns for horses with names classified as fast-sounding compared to the returns for all other horses."

text: "A simple trading strategy of betting against all horses classified as fast-sounding yields a return of approximately 2.9% before the commission but a negative return of −1.6% after deducting the standard commission of 5% from Betfair. This finding could be bracketed under the “limits of arbitrage” argument of Gromb and Vayanos (2010) because the mispricing is not large enough to overcome the transaction costs; thus, potentially misleading or false information is not fully eliminated from prices."

elements.text: "A simple trading strategy of betting against all horses classified as fast-sounding yields a return of approximately 2.9% before the commission but a negative return of −1.6% after deducting the standard commission of 5% from Betfair. This finding could be bracketed under the “limits of arbitrage” argument of Gromb and Vayanos (2010) because the mispricing is not large enough to overcome the transaction costs; thus, potentially misleading or false information is not fully eliminated from prices."

text: Not sure if Mo is being sarcastic or not but yeah I think it'd be hilarious if this could add even a little value to an already profitable strategy. Some situation where you have a profitable strategy, but you can up your belief about your edge slightly when betting against a fast sounding horse, and lower it slightly when betting against a slow sounding horse, and improve your bet sizing or something.

text:
Thanks, what can I say? The last 20 minutes demonstrates the grit, determination, critical thinking, analysis and thoroughness that I think all great traders possess.

So yes, let's lay olympic conqueror as well. I have him down for a .8 on the name scale. Let's cross for a bit there.

But I don't like it as much as I like the "regrettably" back, which I think we should be lifting several ticks worth. Max it. Bet the house. Bet all our houses.

text: As the commission is mentioned here, I can see a strategy on AU horse races I have been doing for the past 12 months is profitable (mostly a straight line), IF the commission is 0-1% (unfortunately), but you know the often 6% (sometime 10%) commission completely destroys any profit. I was wondering if you <@UBS7QANF3> or anyone have any advices on how to deal with it (get some profit out of it), if possible at all. Thanks in advance!

elements.text: As the commission is mentioned here, I can see a strategy on AU horse races I have been doing for the past 12 months is profitable (mostly a straight line), IF the commission is 0-1% (unfortunately), but you know the often 6% (sometime 10%) commission completely destroys any profit. I was wondering if you
or anyone have any advices on how to deal with it (get some profit out of it), if possible at all. Thanks in advance!

text: Combine it with other signals. 2+ signals that individually cannot overcome commission, may be able to in combination.
